Whilst tempests deform the bleak year,</br>Whilst winter yet rages around,</br>When nor roses nor vi'lets appear,</br>Nor cowslips enamel the ground:
"What theme shall young Celadon chuse,</br>What strain shall enliven his song?</br>Alas!  can the peace-loving muse</br>Her notes in this season prolong?
"Shall philosophy brighten the verse?</br>Shall I soar to the regions of day?</br>Or attend on the tear sprinkl'd hearse,</br>While funerals blacken the way?
"Must I leave off the pastoral strain,</br>Must I quit the delights of the field:</br>Or still sing on the desolate plain</br>The joys which contentment can yield.
"Now the birds have forsook ev'ry grove,</br>The groves which all tarnish'd are seen;</br>And my Sylvia, a truant to love,</br>Has left the gay nymphs of the green!
"The charms which each season can bring,</br>Her presence to me could supply;</br>But thy roses of fresh blooming spring,</br>Without her would wither and die.
"Then if Sylvia return to my arms,</br>Sweet music shall flow from my flute,</br>Then the groves shall resound with her charms</br>Tho' the thrush and the linnet are mute.
"I would stray where I saw her appear,</br>Tho' loud tempests around me should blow;</br>I would call it the prime of the year,</br>Tho' the hills were all cover'd with snow."
Thus Celadon, pride of the grove,</br>Rehears'd to the woodlands his grief,</br>And the queen of soft pity and love,</br>Propitious afforded relief.
For Sylvia the lovely, the fair,</br>Return'd to the nymphs of the plain,</br>To the winds fed young Celadon's care;</br>He resum'd his gay humour again.
Her presence new brighten'd the skies,</br>Caus'd the warblers of summer to sing;</br>And fresh flow'rets spontaneous arise</br>To salute the return of the SPRING.</br>
